title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act may be cited as the "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013". It includes pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at increasing work effort and reducing dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The projects will focus on identifying best practices for employment and training programs to help participants secure unsubsidized employment, increase earned income, and decrease reliance on public assistance. The pilot projects aim to increase earned income and reduce reliance on public assistance, including the supplemental nutrition assistance program. Selection criteria include enhancing existing employment and training programs in the State and participating in evaluations on participants' employment activities and post-participation outcomes. The pilot projects aim to increase earned income and reduce reliance on public assistance. Selection criteria include collaborating with the State workforce board, replicability of components, and targeting a variety of populations. The pilot projects target various populations of work registrants, including childless adults, parents, and individuals with low skills or limited work experience. They are selected from a range of existing employment and training programs. The pilot projects target work registrants with limited employment history, providing skills development, post-employment support services, and education leading to recognized credentials or apprenticeships. The pilot projects aim to assist work registrants with limited employment history by providing skills development, post-employment support services, and education leading to recognized credentials or apprenticeships. Projects must include participants from various geographic areas and undergo independent evaluation to measure their impact. The pilot projects aim to assist work registrants with limited employment history by providing skills development, post-employment support services, and education leading to recognized credentials or apprenticeships. Independent evaluation will measure the impact on the target population's ability to find and retain employment, leading to increased household income and reduced dependency. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2017, detailing the outcomes of the pilot projects. The report to Congress will include the results and costs of pilot projects aimed at assisting work registrants with limited employment history. It will also cover the dissemination of findings with State agencies and the necessary steps and funding for future implementation. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2016 to implement pilot projects that show increased employment and earnings. The funds will remain available until expended. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects that comply with the provisions of the Act, cover project costs and administration, and provide information for independent evaluation. The allocated funds for pilot projects cover project costs, administration, providing information for independent evaluation, and cannot replace non-Federal funds for existing employment and training activities.
